The Johns Hopkins Roll Call
hit a new high for the eighteenth
straight year, Alumni Representative Osmar P. Steinwald reported this week.

The check presented to the
University
by
the
Hopkins
Alumni totaled $271,125. This is
an increase of over $40,000 over
last year's donation.
Old Guard Classes •
Again this year, the "old guard
undergraduate classes" of 1886,
1887, 1881, 1889 and 1890 led the
way with 100% participation. The
largest amount presented by one
group was by the undergraduate
school class of 1906.
As has been the custom, donors
of gifts to the University indicated their preferred use. The
University was one of the largest
recipients, with over $82,000 being contributed for unrestricted
purposes. The Hospital received
a total of $17,858. The School of
Medicine received $123,865.
Eisenhower Happy
Eisenhower also stated, "This
alumni fund has a significence
far surpassing what it is in the
percentage of total University
funds. This is the largest single
block of unrestricted funds we
receive, and it allows us to
cement the University together

Banquet
Two top-ranking Hopkins officials Monday agreed with Yale
President Whitney Griswold that
America's educational history
holds lessons for its present and
future, and that the community's
interest in education must be
enlisted to aid the cause of
higher education in the United
States.
Trustee President Charles A.
Garland noted at Commemorathat "Our
ceremonies
tion
ideology of education must be
American and must be tailored
to our own objectives" and that
"we need a better version of our
own kind of education," not a
Russian-induced "crash program,
wherein, the state will triumph
over the mind."

And Devereux C. Josephs, a
member of the Board of Trustees
and Chairman of New York Life
Insurance Co., said at the Alumni
Banquet Monday evening that
"education is not imposed on us
from above but springs from local desires when people decide
what kind of education they

'-Griswold
American education's "greatest need" is a "sense of purpose ... a combination of faith
and conviction that impels us
to take our stated purposes seriously, to have the moral courage to practice what we preach,"
said Yale President A. Whitney
Griswold to an overflow audience
in Shriver Hall Monday at the
84th annual celebration of Commemoration Day.
"This sense of purpose," he
explained, is to be found in "our
own history, our own character,
our own hearts and consciences."
The American educational philosophy, moreover, is "corollary
to our political philosophy. All
citizens are to be educated for
some useful trade or calling. All
who have the desire and the
capacity to assimilate its benefits are to receive a liberal education. Each shall
progress
through his studies as far and
as fast as his native abilities
carry him, on the basis of equal
opportunity, regardless of his
economic or social position. By
these means there shall be
brought about a general diffusion of learning through society
and democracy's need for leaders
in every • field of endeavor Rimn
be served."

A robbery which netted the
thief "approximately $250" in,
cash and checks from the Student Valet Service was disclosed
this week by the service's manager, Bob Kissner.
The sum was found to be missing two weeks after its disappearance from the counter of the
Valet Service shop in the basement of the new dormitory. Disclosure of the incident was delayed "in order to facilitate an
investigation," explained Kissner.
The robbery occured when a
bundle of cash and stamped
checks, which comprised the regular routine cash turn-in to the
central laundry company, was
taken from the shop's counter
after operating hours during the
first week of final exams in January. Assuming that regular
pick-up of the receipts had been
made during off-hours, Kissner
and his partner Morris Jon&
who operate the shop together,
noticed nothing wrong until the
Lord Baltimore Laundry reported
that it had never received the
turn-in over two weeks later.
"The Lord Baltimore Laundry
didn't notice that the money
hadn't been turned in until February 9th because a new secretary had been placed in charge
of accounts at that time,"
Kissner stated. He explained that
the receipts are left on the
counter so that they may be
picked up by the laundry's delivery man, who "did not tell us
about the absent receipts until
the company inquired."

was "obviously made by someone

Wrestling—A Success Story
Hopkins wrestling has met with success. In the first
intercollegiate match in three years, the Hopkins team,
though understandably inexperienced and not fully conditioned, made a showing of which their university is proud.
To coach Cochrane, the diligent team, the loyal fans
and the persistent sports editor of this paper, all credit
is due. A concentrated and vocal minority has done a
great service to Hopkins athletics.
For those of the majority, like the Athletic Director,
who were not impressed by the size of the crowd and who
might tend to underrate wrestling's future accordingly,
they should remember the success of those whom they opposed and should be mindful that Hopkins' stated but
at times abused policy of athletic amateurism does not require crowds as justifications of continuing a sport.

Fledgling No Longer
When this 63-year old newspaper is so thoroughly entrenched it need not fear for its life, but only for its
editors', it has a tendency to sneer at the efforts of other
undergraduate publications. Previously, it had cause to
sneer, for these rival publications were often financially
rickety, editorially trite and totally unreadable, both in
content and format.
But when financial, editorial and news parts of these
magazines are ably handled and when their content apinv

POVERTY CAN BE FUN
It is no disgrace to be poor. It is an error, but it is no disgrace.
So if your purse is empty, do not skulk and brood and hide
Your head in shame. Stand tall. Admit your poverty. Admit it
freely and frankly and all kinds of good things will happen to
you. Take, for instance, the case of Blossom Sigafoos.
Blossom, an impecunious freshman at an Eastern girls'
college, was smart as a whip and round as a dumpling, and
Scarcely a day went by when she didn't get invited to a party
weekend at one of the nearby men's schools. But Blossom never
accepted. She did not have the rail fare; she did not have the
Clothes. Weekend after weekend, while her classmates went
frolicking, Blossom sat alone, saved from utter despair only by
her pack of Marlboros, for even an exchequer as slim as Blossom's can afford the joys of Marlboro—joys far beyond their
Paltry price: rich, mellow tobaccos, lovingly cured and carefully packed; a new improved filter that works like a charm.
Croesus himself could not buy a better cigarette!
However, Marlboro's most passionate admirers—among
Whose number I am paid to count myself —would not claim
that Nfarlboro can entirely replace love and romance, and Blossom grew steadily moroser.

4://aviipz o'kt06.ededEpfigzier.
Then one day came a phone call from an intelligent sophomore named Tom O'Shanter at a nearby men's college. "Blossom," said Tom,"I want you to come down next week for the
barley festival, and I won't take no for an answer.'!
"No," said Blossom.
"Foolish girl," said Tom gently."I know why you refuse me.
It is because you are poor, isn't it?';
"Yes," said Blossom.
"I will send you a railroad ticket," said Tom. "Also a small
salami in case you get hungry on the train."
"But I have nothing to wear," said Blossom.
Tom replied, "I will send you one suit of cashmere, two
gowns of lace, three slacks of velvet,four shoes of calf, five socks
of nylon, and a partridge in a pear tree."
"That is most kind," said Blossom, "but I fear I cannot
dance and enjoy myself while back home my poor lame brother
Tiny Tim lies abed."
"Send him to Mayo Brothers and put it on my tab," said
Toni.
"You are terribly decent," said Blossom,"but I cannot come
to your party because
. all the other girls at the party will be
from rich, distinguished families, and my father is but a humble
Woodcutter"
"I will buy him Yosemite," said Tom.
"You have a great heart," said Blossom. 'Hold the phone
While I ask our wise and kindly old Dean of Women whether it
is proper for me to accept all these gifts."
She went forthwith and asked the Dean of Women, and
the Dean of Women laid her wise and kindly old hand on
Elossom's cheek and said, "Child, let not false pride rob you
of happiness. Accept these gifts from Tom."
"Lord love you, Wise and Kindly," breathed Blossom, dropPing grateful tears into the Dean's reticule. "I must run and
tell Tom."
"Yes, run, child," said the Dean, a smile wrinkling her wise
and kindly old eyes."And ask him has he got an older brother."

The Johns Hopkins varsity
fencing team enters a six-man
squad in tomorrow's Middle Atlantic championships to be held
at Stevens Institute.

among the tournament leaders,
own a 2-3 conference record as

the Pennsylvanians, the sabre
division made an exceptionally
strong showing, with Leo Appel
and Paul Karol each taking all
three bouts, while Sandy Levin
took one. Since the top two men
from each weapon go the championships, Appel and Karol will
represent the sabre squad.

Venza and Barry Jasper each

The Johns Hopkins freshman
basketball team closed out its
1958-59 home season last Saturday night with a 78-76 last minute victory over Bainbridge Prep.
The Blue Jay yearlings, trailing 69-62 with four minutes left
in the game, came on fast to tie
the score at 70-70. From that
point on each team matched the
other basket for basket until the
last 19 seconds of play when Put
Boyer dropped in a shot from the
field to give the Blue a two-point
victory.
Team Performance
Bill Mahoney led the balanced
attack with 24 markers, 20 of
which came in the first .half,
while contributing 15 rebounds
against taller opponents in what
was undoubtedly his best allround performance of the year.
Boyer, in addition to his all-important game winning basket,
scored 19 markers on the night.
Stan Weiss, with 13 points,
came through with several crucial
plays in the game's waning moments. John Doud pitched in
with 12 points and 12 rebounds,
while Ed McCaffery, operating
with a 4 foul handicap in the
second half, again directed the
entire offensive, scoring 10 points

Wrestling—A Success Story
Hopkins wrestling has met with success. In the first
intercollegiate match in three years, the Hopkins team,
though understandably inexperienced and not fully conditioned, made a showing of which their university is proud.
To coach Cochrane, the diligent team, the loyal fans
and the persistent sports editor of this paper, all credit
is due. A concentrated and vocal minority has done a
great service to Hopkins athletics.
For those of the majority, like the Athletic Director,
who were not impressed by the size of the crowd and who
might tend to underrate wrestling's future accordingly,
they should remember the success of those whom they opposed and should be mindful that Hopkins' stated but
at times abused policy of athletic amateurism does not require crowds as justifications of continuing a sport.

Fledgling No Longer
When this 63-year old newspaper is so thoroughly entrenched it need not fear for its life, but only for its
editors', it has a tendency to sneer at the efforts of other
undergraduate publications. Previously, it had cause to
sneer, for these rival publications were often financially
rickety, editorially trite and totally unreadable, both in
content and format.
But when financial, editorial and news parts of these
magazines are ably handled and when their content apinv

POVERTY CAN BE FUN
It is no disgrace to be poor. It is an error, but it is no disgrace.
So if your purse is empty, do not skulk and brood and hide
Your head in shame. Stand tall. Admit your poverty. Admit it
freely and frankly and all kinds of good things will happen to
you. Take, for instance, the case of Blossom Sigafoos.
Blossom, an impecunious freshman at an Eastern girls'
college, was smart as a whip and round as a dumpling, and
Scarcely a day went by when she didn't get invited to a party
weekend at one of the nearby men's schools. But Blossom never
accepted. She did not have the rail fare; she did not have the
Clothes. Weekend after weekend, while her classmates went
frolicking, Blossom sat alone, saved from utter despair only by
her pack of Marlboros, for even an exchequer as slim as Blossom's can afford the joys of Marlboro—joys far beyond their
Paltry price: rich, mellow tobaccos, lovingly cured and carefully packed; a new improved filter that works like a charm.
Croesus himself could not buy a better cigarette!
However, Marlboro's most passionate admirers—among
Whose number I am paid to count myself —would not claim
that Nfarlboro can entirely replace love and romance, and Blossom grew steadily moroser.

4://aviipz o'kt06.ededEpfigzier.
Then one day came a phone call from an intelligent sophomore named Tom O'Shanter at a nearby men's college. "Blossom," said Tom,"I want you to come down next week for the
barley festival, and I won't take no for an answer.'!
"No," said Blossom.
"Foolish girl," said Tom gently."I know why you refuse me.
It is because you are poor, isn't it?';
"Yes," said Blossom.
"I will send you a railroad ticket," said Tom. "Also a small
salami in case you get hungry on the train."
"But I have nothing to wear," said Blossom.
Tom replied, "I will send you one suit of cashmere, two
gowns of lace, three slacks of velvet,four shoes of calf, five socks
of nylon, and a partridge in a pear tree."
"That is most kind," said Blossom, "but I fear I cannot
dance and enjoy myself while back home my poor lame brother
Tiny Tim lies abed."
"Send him to Mayo Brothers and put it on my tab," said
Toni.
"You are terribly decent," said Blossom,"but I cannot come
to your party because
. all the other girls at the party will be
from rich, distinguished families, and my father is but a humble
Woodcutter"
"I will buy him Yosemite," said Tom.
"You have a great heart," said Blossom. 'Hold the phone
While I ask our wise and kindly old Dean of Women whether it
is proper for me to accept all these gifts."
She went forthwith and asked the Dean of Women, and
the Dean of Women laid her wise and kindly old hand on
Elossom's cheek and said, "Child, let not false pride rob you
of happiness. Accept these gifts from Tom."
"Lord love you, Wise and Kindly," breathed Blossom, dropPing grateful tears into the Dean's reticule. "I must run and
tell Tom."
"Yes, run, child," said the Dean, a smile wrinkling her wise
and kindly old eyes."And ask him has he got an older brother."

Blue Jay Bladesmen
Journey To Stevens
Seeking M-A Crown
By HERB DORSEY
The Johns Hopkins varsity
fencing team enters a six-man
squad in tomorrow's Middle Atlantic championships to be held
at Stevens Institute.
The Jays, expected to finish
among the tournament leaders,
own a 2-3 conference record as
a result of last Saturday's 12-15
loss at Haverford College. Against
the Pennsylvanians, the sabre
division made an exceptionally
strong showing, with Leo Appel
and Paul Karol each taking all
three bouts, while Sandy Levin
took one. Since the top two men
from each weapon go the championships, Appel and Karol will

The Johns Hopkins freshman
basketball team closed out its
1958-59 home season last Saturday night with a 78-76 last minute victory over Bainbridge Prep.
The Blue Jay yearlings, trailing 69-62 with four minutes left
in the game, came on fast to tie
the score at 70-70. From that
point on each team matched the
other basket for basket until the
last 19 seconds of play when Put
Boyer dropped in a shot from the
field to give the Blue a two-point
victory.
Team Performance
Bill Mahoney led the balanced
attack with 24 markers, 20 of
which came in the first .half,
while contributing 15 rebounds
against taller opponents in what
was undoubtedly his best allround performance of the year.
Boyer, in addition to his all-important game winning basket,
scored 19 markers on the night.
Stan Weiss, with 13 points,
came through with several crucial
plays in the game's waning moments. John Doud pitched in
with 12 points and 12 rebounds,
while Ed McCaffery, operating
with a 4 foul handicap in the
second half, again directed the
entire offensive, scoring 10 points
